article.paragraph: TheChicago White Soxare anUnited StatesAmericanprofessionalbaseballteam based in theSouth Side, ChicagoSouth SideofChicago,Illinois. The White Sox are members of theAmerican League(AL)American League CentralCentraldivision inMajor League Baseball(MLB). The White Sox play their home games atU.S. Cellular Field. They are one of two major league clubs in Chicago; the other is theChicago Cubs, who are a member of theNational League(NL)National League CentralCentraldivision. The team is currently owned byJerry Reinsdorf.

One of the American League's eight charterMajor North American professional sports teamsfranchises, the Chicago team was established as a major league baseball club inbaseball year1900. The club was originally called the Chicago White Stockings, but this was soon shortened to Chicago White Sox. The team played home games atSouth Side Parkbefore, inbaseball year1910, moving toComiskey Parkfor the next eight decades.

The White Sox won the1906 World Serieswith a defense-oriented team dubbed "the Hitless Wonders", and the1917 World Seriesled byEddie Cicotte,Eddie Collins, andShoeless Joe Jackson. The1919 World Serieswas marred by theBlack Sox Scandal, in which several members of the White Sox were accused of conspiring with gamblers toMatch fixingfix games. In response, Major League Baseball's newCommissioner of BaseballCommissionerKenesaw Mountain Landisbanned the players from Major League Baseball for life. In1959 Chicago White Sox season1959, led byEarly Wynn,Nellie Fox,Luis Aparicioand managerAl Lopez, the White Sox won theList of American League pennant winnersAmerican League pennant. They won the AL pennant again in2005 Chicago White Sox season2005, when they also went on to win the2005 World SeriesWorld Series.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: MainHistory of the Chicago White SoxFile:1906 Chicago White Sox.jpgthumbrightx200px1906 White Sox, with club founder Charles ComiskeyThe White Sox originated as the Sioux City Cornhuskers of theWestern League (original)Western League, aminor leagueunder the parameters of the National Agreement with theNational League. In 1894,Charles Comiskeybought the Cornhuskers and moved them toSt. Paul, Minnesota, where they became theSt. Paul Saints. In 1900, with the approval of Western League presidentBan Johnson, Charles Comiskey moved the Saints into his hometown neighborhood ofArmour Square, Chicago, where they became known as theWhite Stockings,the former name of Chicago's National League team, the Orphans (now theChicago Cubs).cite webBovaGeorgeSox Fans' Guide to Sox Uniformshttp://www.whitesoxinteractive.com/rwas/index.php?categoryFlyingSock.ComWhite Sox InteractiveOctober 11, 2014

In1901 Major League Baseball season1901, the Western League broke the National Agreement and became the new major leagueAmerican League. The very first season in the American League ended with a White Stockings championship.cite webhttp://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/AL/1901.shtml1901 American League Team Statistics and Standings[[Baseball Reference]][[Sports Reference]]May 25, 2015However, that would be the end of the season as theWorld Seriesdid not begin until1903 World Series1903.cite webStezanoMartin6 Things You May Not Know About the World Serieshttp://www.history.com/news/6-things-you-may-not-know-about-the-world-seriesOctober 24, 2012[[History (TV channel)|History]][[A&E Television Networks]]October 11, 2014The franchise, now known as theChicago White Sox, made its first World Series appearance in1906 World Series1906, beating the crosstown Cubs in six games.Cite webhttp://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1906_WS.shtml1906 World SeriesSports ReferenceBaseball ReferenceJanuary 2, 2010

The White Sox would win a third pennant and second World Series in1917 Chicago White Sox season1917, beating the1917 New York Giants seasonNew York Giantsin six games with help from starsEddie CicotteandShoeless Joe"Shoeless" Joe Jackson.Cite webhttp://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1917_WS.shtml1917 World SeriesSports ReferenceBaseball ReferenceJanuary 2, 2010The Sox were heavily favored in the1919 World Series, but lost to the1919 Cincinnati Reds seasonCincinnati Redsin 8 games. Huge bets on the Reds fueled speculation that the series had beenMatch fixingfixed. A criminal investigation went on in the 1920 season, and though all players were acquitted, commissionerKenesaw Mountain Landisbanned eight of the White Sox players for life, in what was known as theBlack Sox Scandal.cite webThe Black Soxhttp://www.chicagohs.org/history/blacksox.html[[Chicago Historical Society]]October 11, 2014This set the franchise back, as they did not win another pennant for 40 years.

The White Sox did not finish in the upper half of the American League again until after club founder Charles Comiskey died and passed ownership of the club to his son,J. Louis Comiskey.cite webJ. Louis Comiskeyhttp://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?nameBaseball LibraryIdea LogicalMay 25, 2015They finished in the upper half most years between 1936-1946 under the leadership of managerJimmy Dykes, with star shortstopLuke Appling, known as Ol' Aches and Pains, and pitcherTed Lyons. Appling and Lyons have their numbers 4 and 16 retired.cite webRetired Numbershttp://chicago.whitesox.mlb.com/cws/history/retired_numbers.jspWhiteSox.com[[MLB Advanced Media]]October 11, 2014

After J. Louis Comiskey died in 1939, ownership of the club was passed down to his widow,Grace Comiskey. The club was later passed down to Grace's childrenDorothy Comiskey RigneyDorothyandChuck ComiskeyChuckin 1956, with Dorothy selling a majority share to a group led byBill Veeckafter the1958 Chicago White Sox season1958 season.cite webAll-Time Ownershttp://chicago.whitesox.mlb.com/cws/history/owners.jspWhiteSox.comMLB Advanced MediaOctober 11, 2014Veeck was notorious for his promotional stunts, attracting fans toComiskey Parkwith the new "exploding scoreboard" and outfield shower. In 1961,Arthur Allyn, Jr.briefly owned the club before selling to his brotherJohn Allyn.

File:Al Lopez - WJROneOfAKind.jpgthumbrightx150pxAl Lopez, manager of the Go-Go White SoxFrom 1951-1967, the White Sox had their longest period of sustained success, scoring a winning record for 17 straight seasons. Known as the "Go-Go White Sox" for their tendency to focus on speed and getting on base versus power hitting, they featured stars such asMinnie Minoso,cite webMinnie Minosohttp://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/minosmi01.shtmlBaseball ReferenceSports ReferenceOctober 11, 2014Nellie Fox,cite webNellie Foxhttp://www.baseball-reference.com/players/f/foxne01.shtmlBaseball ReferenceSports ReferenceOctober 11, 2014Luis Aparicio,cite webLuis Apariciohttp://www.baseball-reference.com/players/a/aparilu01.shtmlBaseball ReferenceSport ReferenceOctober 11, 2014Billy Pierce,cite webBilly Piercehttp://www.baseball-reference.com/players/p/piercbi02.shtmlBaseball ReferenceSport ReferenceOctober 11, 2014andSherm Lollar.cite webSherm Lollarhttp://www.baseball-reference.com/players/l/lollash01.shtmlBaseball ReferenceSport ReferenceOctober 11, 2014From 1957-1965, the Sox were managed byAl Lopez. The Sox finished in the upper half of the American League in eight of his nine seasons, including six years in the top two of the league.cite webAl Lopezhttp://www.baseball-reference.com/managers/lopezal01.shtmlBaseball ReferenceSport ReferenceOctober 11, 2014In1959 Chicago White Sox season1959, the White Sox ended theNew York Yankeesdominance over the American League, and won their first pennant since the ill-fated 1919 campaign.cite web1959 Chicago White Sox seasonhttp://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CHW/1959.shtmlBaseball ReferenceSport ReferenceOctober 11, 2014Despite winning game one of the1959 World Series11-0, they fell to theLos Angeles Dodgersin six games.cite web1959 World Serieshttp://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/history/postseason/mlb_ws_recaps.jsp?featureMLB.comMLB Advanced MediaOctober 11, 2014

The late 60s and the 70s were a tumultuous time for the Sox, as they struggled to win games and attract fans. Allyn andBud Seligagreed to a handshake deal that would give Selig control of the club and move them toMilwaukee; however, this was blocked by the American League.cite webBovaGeorgeSave Our Sox!http://whitesoxinteractive.com/History&Glory/SaveOurSox.htmFlyingSock.comWhite Sox InteractiveMay 25, 2015Selig instead bought theSeattle Pilotsand moved them to Milwaukee, putting enormous pressure on the American League to place a team inSeattle. A plan was in place for the Sox to move to Seattle and forCharlie Finleyto move hisOakland A'sto Chicago. However, Chicago had a renewed interest in the Sox after the 1972 season, and the American League instead added the expansionSeattle Mariners. The1972 Chicago White Sox season1972 White Soxwere one of the lone successful season of this era, asDick Allenwound up winning the American League MVP award.cite webDick Allenhttp://www.baseball-reference.com/players/a/allendi01.shtml?redirBaseball ReferenceSport ReferenceOctober 11, 2014Some have said that Dick Allen is responsible for saving the White Sox in Chicago. Bill Veeck returned as owner of the Sox in 1975, and despite not having much money, they managed to win 90 games in1977 Chicago White Sox season1977, a team known as the South Side Hitmen.

However, the team's fortunes plummeted after the 1977 season, plagued by 90-loss teams and scarred by the notoriousDisco Demolition Nightpromotion in 1979.cite newsVettelPhilSteve Dahl's Disco Demolition at Comiskey Parkhttp://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/chi-chicagodays-disco-story-story.html[[Chicago Tribune]]October 11, 2014Bill Veeck was forced to sell the team. He rejected offers from ownership groups intent on moving the club toDenver, eventually agreeing to sell the club toEdward J. DeBartolo, Sr.Ed DeBartolo, who was the only prospective owner who promised to keep the Sox in Chicago. However, DeBartolo was rejected by the owners, and the club was then sold to a group headed byJerry ReinsdorfandEddie Einhorn. The Reinsdorf era started off well, as the Sox won their first division title in1983 Chicago White Sox season1983, led by managerTony La Russacite webTony La Russahttp://www.baseball-reference.com/managers/larusto01.shtmlBaseball ReferenceSport ReferenceOctober 11, 2014and starsCarlton Fisk,Tom Paciorek,Ron Kittle,Harold Baines, andLaMarr Hoyt.cite web1983 Chicago White Sox Seasonhttp://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CHW/1983.shtmlBaseball ReferenceSport ReferenceOctober 11, 2014During the 1986 season, La Russa was fired by announcer-turned-GMKen Harrelson. La Russa went on to manage in six World Series (winning 3) with theOakland A'sandSt. Louis Cardinals, ending up in theNational Baseball Hall of FameHall of Fameas the third-winningest manager of all time.cite webGarfeinChuckHawk Opens Up on Firing La Russahttp://www.csnchicago.com/blog/sox-drawer/hawk-opens-firing-la-russaFebruary 4, 2013[[CSN Chicago]]May 26, 2015

File:Frank Thomas 1997.jpgthumbFrank Thomas in 1997The White Sox struggled for the rest of the 80s, as Chicago fought to keep the Sox in town. Reinsdorf wanted to replace the agingComiskey Park, and sought public funds to do so. When talks stalled, there was a strong offer to move the team to theTampa, Floridaarea.cite webSullivanPaul FrancisThe Franchise moves that never happenedhttp://www.hardballtimes.com/the-franchise-moves-that-almost-happened/June 21, 2011[[The Hardball Times]]May 26, 2015Funding for a new ballpark was approved in an 11th hour deal by theIllinois State Legislatureon June 30, 1988, with the stipulation that new park had to be built on the corner of 35th and Shields, across the street from the old ballpark, as opposed to the suburban ballpark the owners had designed.Architects offered to redesign the ballpark to a more "retro" feel that would fit in the city blocks around Comiskey Park; however, the ownership group was set on a 1991 open date, and so they kept the old design.cite webBovaGeorgeA Conversation with Phillip Besshttp://whitesoxinteractive.com/FixComiskey/Bess/Conversation1.htmFlyingSock.comWhite Sox InteractiveOctober 11, 2014In 1991, thenew Comiskey Parkopened. However, it would be rendered obsolete a year later with the opening of the retro-inspiredOriole Park at Camden Yards. The park, now known asU.S. Cellular Field, underwent many renovations in the early 2000s to give it a more retro feel.

The White Sox were fairly successful in the 1990s and early 2000s, with 12 winning seasons between 1990-2005. First BasemanFrank Thomas (designated hitter)Frank Thomasbecame the face of the franchise, ending his career as the White Sox' all-time leader in runs, doubles, home runs, total bases and walks.cite webFrank Thomashttp://baseballhall.org/hof/thomas-frank[[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum]]October 11, 2014Other major players includedRobin Ventura,Ozzie Guillen,Jack McDowell, andBobby Thigpen.cite web1993 Chicago White Soxhttp://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CHW/1993.shtmlBaseball ReferenceSport ReferenceOctober 11, 2014The Sox would win the West division in1993 Chicago White Sox season1993, and were in first place in1994 Chicago White Sox season1994when the season was cancelled due to the1994 MLB Strike.

In2004 Chicago White Sox season2004, Ozzie Guillen was hired as manager of his former team.cite webGuillen Back with White Sox as Managerhttp://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?idNovember 5, 2003[[ESPN]]May 25, 2015After finishing second in 2004, the Sox won 99 games and the Central Division title in2005 Chicago White Sox season2005behind the work of starsPaul Konerko,Mark Buehrle,A.J. Pierzynski,Joe Crede, andOrlando Hernandez.cite web2005 Chicago White Soxhttp://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CHW/2005.shtmlBaseball ReferenceSport ReferenceOctober 11, 2014They started the playoffs by sweeping the defending champion2005 Boston Red Sox seasonBoston Red Soxin theALDS, and then beat the2005 Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim seasonAngelsin 5 games to win their first pennant in 46 years, thanks to 4 complete games by the White Sox rotation.cite web2005 ALCShttp://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/2005_ALCS.shtmlBaseball ReferenceSport ReferenceOctober 11, 2014The White Sox went on to sweep the2005 Houston Astros seasonHouston Astrosin the2005 World Series, giving the Sox their first World Championship in 88 years.cite webWhite Sox end 88-year drought, sweep Astros to win World Serieshttp://scores.espn.go.com/mlb/recap?gameIdOctober 27, 2005ESPNMay 25, 2015

Guillen had marginal success during the rest of his tenure, with the Sox winning the Central Division title in2008 Chicago White Sox season2008after a2008 American League Central tie-breaker gameone game playoffwith the2008 Minnesota Twins seasonMinnesota Twins.cite webMerkinScottWhite Sox claim AL Central Crownhttp://m.whitesox.mlb.com/news/article/3576317/October 1, 2008WhiteSox.comMLB Advanced MediaMay 25, 2015However, Guillen left the White Sox after the2011 Chicago White Sox season2011 season, and was replaced by former teammateRobin Ventura. The White Sox finished the2015 Chicago White Sox season2015 season, their 115th in Chicago, with a 76-86 record, a 3-game improvement over2014 Chicago White Sox season2014.cite webvan SchouwenDarylWhite Sox blanked in fitting finish to 2015http://chicago.suntimes.com/baseball/7/71/1011803/white-sox-blanked-tigers-season-finaleOctober 4, 2015Chicago Sun-TimesOctober 9, 2015Ventura is expected to return in 2016, with a young core featuringJose Abreu (baseball)Jose Abreu,Adam Eaton (outfielder)Adam Eaton,Jose Quintana, andChris Sale.cite web2014 Chicago White Sox seasonhttp://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CHW/2014.shtmlBaseball ReferenceSport ReferenceOctober 11, 2014
article.heading: Ballparks
article.paragraph: In the late 1980s, the franchise threatened to relocate toTampa Bay AreaTampa Bay(as did theSan Francisco Giants), but franticcite newshttp://articles.chicagotribune.com/1988-05-12/news/8803160481_1_sox-owners-comiskey-park-james-thompsonChicago TribuneJohnKassThompson: Sox Vow To Stay If Bill PassesMay 12, 1988lobbying on the part of the Illinois governorJames R. Thompsonand state legislature resulted in approval (by one vote) of public funding for a new stadium. Although designed primarily as a baseball stadium (as opposed to a "multipurpose" stadium) New Comiskey Park (redubbedU.S. Cellular Fieldin 2003) was built in a 1960s style similar toDodger StadiumandKauffman Stadium. It opened inbaseball year1991to positive reviews; many praised its wide open concourses, excellent sight lines, and natural grass (unlike other stadiums of the era such asRogers Centrein Toronto). However, it was quickly overshadowed in the public imagination by the wave of "nostalgia" or "retro" ballparks, beginning withOriole Park at Camden Yards. The park's inaugural season drew 2,934,154 fans  at the time, an all-time attendance record for any Chicago baseball team.

File:Uscellular.jpgthumb250pxView from the upper deck of U.S. Cellular Field in 2006Despite a number of innovations in its original construction  including a lower deck concourse that circumscribes the entire stadium, allowing a view of the game from any location  the park was often criticized for its sterile appearance and steep upper deck.

In recent years, money accrued from the sale of naming rights toU.S. Cellularhas been allocated for renovations to make the park more aesthetically appealing and fan friendly. Notable renovations of early phases included: re-orientation of the bullpens parallel to the field of play (thus decreasing slightly the formerly symmetrical dimensions of the outfield); filling seats in up to and shortening the outfield wall; ballooning foul-line seat sections out toward the field of play; creating a new multi-tieredbatter's eye, allowing fans to see out through one-way screens from the center-field vantage point, and complete with concession stand and bar-style seating on its 'fan deck'; renovating all concourse areas with brick, historic murals, and new concession stand ornaments to establish a more friendly feel. The stadium's steel and concrete was repainted dark gray and black. The scoreboard Jumbotron was also replaced with a newMitsubishiDiamondvisionHigh-definition televisionHDTVgiant screen.

More recently, the top quarter of the upper deck was removed inbaseball year2004and a black wrought metal roof was placed over it, covering all but the first eight rows of seats. This decreasedseating capacityfrom 47,098 to 40,615. 2005 also saw the introduction of the Scout Seats, redesignating (and re-upholstering) 200 lower deck seats behind home plate as an exclusive area, with seat-side waitstaff and a complete restaurant located underneath the concourse. The most significant structural addition besides the new roof wasbaseball year2005's FUNdamentals Deck, a multi-tiered structure on the left field concourse containing batting cages, a smallTee Ballfield, speed pitch, and several other child-themed activities intended to entertain and educate young fans with the help of coaching staff from the Chicago Bulls/Sox Training Academy. This structure was used during the 2005 playoffs byESPNandFox Broadcasting Companyas a broadcasting platform.

Designed as a 7-phase plan, the renovations were completed before thebaseball year2007season with the 7th and final phase. The most visible renovation in this final phase was replacing the original blue seats with green seats. The upper deck already had new green seats, put in before the beginning of the 2006 season. Beginning with thebaseball year2007season a new luxury seating section was added in the former press box. This section has amenities similar to those of the Scout Seats section. After the 2007 season the ballpark continued renovation projects despite that the 7-phase plan was complete.
article.heading: Previous ballparks
article.paragraph: File:00118 n 9abwn9hwm1496.jpgthumb250pxBatting practice at Comiskey Park in 1986The St. Paul Saints first played their games atLexington Park.cite webThornleyStewTwin Cities Ballparkshttp://stewthornley.net/twincityballparks.htmlstewthornley.net2004May 26, 2015When they moved to Chicago'sArmour Squareneighborhood, they began play at theSouth Side Park#South Side Park III (1900-1940)South Side Park. Previously aCricketgrounds, the park was located on the north side of 39th Street (now called Pershing Road) between South Wentworth and South Princeton Avenues.cite webU.S. Cellular Field Historyhttp://chicago.whitesox.mlb.com/cws/ballpark/information/index.jsp?contentWhiteSox.comMLB Advanced MediaJune 8, 2014Its massive dimensions yielded few home runs, which was to the advantage of the White Sox'1906 Chicago White Sox seasonHitless Wondersteams of the early 20th century.cite webHealeyPaulSouth Side Parkhttp://projectballpark.org/history/ua/southside3.htmlProject BallparkJune 8, 2014

After the 1909 season, the Sox moved 5 blocks to the north to play in the newComiskey Park, while the 39th Street grounds became the home of theChicago American Giants. Billed as the Baseball Palace of the World, it originally held 28,000 seats and eventually grew to hold over 50,000.cite webFletcherDavid J.Never on a Fridayhttp://www.chicagobaseballmuseum.org/chicago-baseball-museum-Comisky-Park.phpChicago Baseball MuseumJune 8, 2014It became known for its many odd features, such as the outdoor shower and the exploding scoreboard. When it closed after the1990 Chicago White Sox season1990 season, it was the oldest ballpark still inMajor League Baseball.

On November 19, 2007, the cities ofGlendale, ArizonaandPhoenix, Arizonabroke ground on the Cactus League's newest Spring Training facility.Camelback Ranch, the $76 million two-team facility will be the new home of both the White Sox and theLos Angeles Dodgersfor their Spring Training programs. Aside fromstate-of-the-artbaseball facilities at the 10,000-seat stadium the location includes residential, restaurant and retail development, a 4-star hotel and 18-holegolf course. Other amenities includeconvert118000sqftm2onof Major and minor league clubhouses for the two teams, four Major League practice fields and eight minor league practice fields, two practice infields and parking to accommodate 5,000 vehicles.cite webhttp://www.glendaleaz.com/news/062607_baseball.cfmLet's Play Ball!June 26, 2007[[Glendale, Arizona|Glendale AZ]]May 26, 2015
article.heading: Logos and uniforms
article.paragraph: See alsoMajor League Baseball uniformsOver the years the White Sox have become noted for many of theirbaseball uniformuniforminnovations and changes. In 1960, the White Sox became the first team in the major sports to put players' last names onjersey (clothing)#In sportsjerseys.

In 1912 the White Sox debuted one of the most enduring and famouslogosin baseballa large "S" in a Roman-stylefont, with a small "O" inside the top loop of the "S" and a small "X" inside the bottom loop. This is the logo associated with the 1917 World Series championship team and the 1919 Black Sox. With a couple of brief interruptions, the dark-blue logo with the large "S" lasted through 1938 (but continued in a modified block style into the 1940s). Through the 1940s, the White Sox team colors were primarily navy blue trimmed with red.

The White Sox logo in the 1950s and 1960s (actually beginning in the 1949 season) was the word "SOX" in an Old English font, diagonally arranged, with the "S" larger than the other two letters. From 1949 through 1963, the primary color was black (trimmed with red after 1951). The Old English "SOX" in black lettering is the logo associated with the Go-Go Sox era.

In 1964, the primary color went back to navy blue, and the road uniforms changed from gray to pale blue. In 1971, the team's primary color changed from royal blue to red, with the color of theirpin stripespinstripesandbaseball capcapschanging to red. The 19711975 uniform included redbaseball uniform#Stockings and pantssocks.

link.part: Chicago White Sox logo from 1976 to 1987

article.paragraph: In 1976 the team's uniforms changed again. The team's primary color changed back from red to navy. The team based their uniforms on a style worn in the early days of the franchise, with white jerseys worn at home, blue on theroad (sports)road. The team brought back white socks for the last time in team history. The socks featured a different stripe pattern every year. The team also had the option to wear blue or white pants with either jersey. Additionally the teams "SOX" logo was changed to a modern-looking "SOX" in a bold font, with 'CHICAGO' written across the jersey. Finally, the team's logo featured asilhouetteof a batter over the words "SOX".

The new uniforms also featuredcollar (clothing)collarsand were designed to be worn untucked  both unprecedented. Yet by far the most unusual wrinkle was the option to wear shorts, which the White Sox did for the first game of adoubleheader (baseball)doubleheaderagainst theKansas City Royalsin 1976. TheHollywood Starsof thePacific Coast Leaguehad previously tried the same concept, it was also poorly received. Apart from aesthetic issues, as a practical matter shorts are not conducive to sliding, due to the likelihood of significant abrasions.

Upon taking over the team in 1980 new ownersEddie EinhornandJerry Reinsdorfannounced a contest where fans were invited to create new uniforms for the White Sox. The winning entry was submitted by a fan where the word "SOX" was written across the front of the jersey, in the same font as a cap, inside of a large blue stripe trimmed with red. The red and blue stripes were also on the sleeves, and the road jerseys were gray to the home whites. In those jerseys the White Sox won 99 games and the AL West championship in 1983, the best record in the majors.

link.part: Alternate logo, on road uniforms from 1990 to 2011

article.paragraph: After five years those uniforms were retired and replaced with a more basic uniform which had "White Sox" written across the front in script, with "Chicago" on the front of the road jersey. The cap logo was also changed to a cursive "C", although the batter logo was retained for several years.
For a mid-season 1990 game at Comiskey Park the White Sox appeared once in a uniform based on that of the 1917 White Sox.

The White Sox then switched their regular uniform style once more. In September, for the final series at Old Comiskey Park, the old English "SOX" logo (a slightly simplified version of the 194963 logo) was restored, and the new uniform also had the black pinstripes restored. The team's primary color changed back to black, this time with silver trim. The team also introduced a new flying sock logo which appeared as a sleeve patch on the away and alternate uniforms until 2011 when the patch was switched with the primary logo on the away uniform. With minor modifications (i.e., occasionally wearing vests, black game jerseys) the White Sox have used this style ever since.

During the 2012 and 2013 seasons, the White Sox wore their throwback uniforms at home every Sunday, starting with the 1972 red-pinstriped throwback jerseys worn during the 2012 season, followed by the 198186 uniforms the next season. In the 2014 season, the "Winning Ugly" throwbacks were promoted to full-time alternate status, and is now worn at home on select dates. In one game during the 2014 season, the White Sox paired their throwbacks with a cap featuring the batter logo instead of the wordmark "SOX"; this is currently their batting practice cap prior to games in the throwback uniforms.
article.heading: Culture
Nicknames
article.paragraph: The White Sox were originally known as the White Stockings, a reference to the original name of theChicago Cubs.cite webChicago Cubs Team History & Encyclopediahttp://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CHC/Baseball ReferenceSports ReferenceDecember 28, 2014To fit the name in headlines, local newspapers such as theChicago Tribuneabbreviated the name alternatively to Stox and Sox.cite journalEngberDanielX Marks The Baseball teamhttp://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/2005/10/x_marks_the_baseball_team.htmlOctober 25, 2015[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]ExplainerMay 25, 2015Charles Comiskey would officially adopt the White Sox nickname in the club's first years, making them the first team to officially use the "Sox" name. The Chicago White Sox are most prominentlyList of baseball team nicknamesnicknamed"the South Siders", based on their particularSouth Side, Chicagodistrict within Chicago. Other nicknames include the synonymous "Pale Hose";cite webDeFordFrankThe Finest Nickname in Baseballhttp://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyIdMay 18, 2005National Public RadioMay 25, 2015"the ChiSox", a combination of "Chicago" and "Sox", used mostly by the national media to differentiate them between the Boston Red Sox (BoSox); and "the Good Guys", a reference to the team's one-time motto "Good guys wear black", coined by broadcasterKen Harrelson. Most fans and Chicago media refer to the team as simply "the Sox". TheSpanish languagemedia sometimes refer to the team asMedias Blancasfor "White Socks."
Several White Sox teams have received nicknames over the years:

list.listitem: The1906 Chicago White Sox season1906 teamwere known as theHitless Wonders,due to their .230 batting average, worst in the American League.cite web1906: The Hitless Wondershttp://www.thisgreatgame.com/1906-baseball-history.htmlThis Great GameDecember 28, 2014Despite their hitting woes, the Sox would beat the crosstown Cubs for their first world title.
The1919 Chicago White Sox season1919 White Soxare known as theBlack Sox,after 8 players were banned from baseball for fixing the1919 World Series.

The1959 Chicago White Sox season1959 White Soxwere referred to as theGo-Go White Soxdue to their speed-based offense. The period from 1950-1964, in which the White Sox had 15 consecutive winning seasons, is sometimes referred to as the Go-Go Era.cite newsSecterBobThe 1959 'Go-Go' White Sox and the air-raid sirenshttp://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/chi-chicagodays-whitesox1959-story-story.htmlChicago TribuneDecember 28, 2014
The1977 Chicago White Sox season1977 teamwere known as theSouth Side Hitmenas they contended for the division title after finishing last1976 Chicago White Sox seasonthe year before.

The1983 Chicago White Sox season1983 White Soxbecame known as theWinning Ugly White Soxin response toTexas Rangers (baseball)Texas RangersmanagerDoug Rader's derisive comments that the White Sox "...weren't playing well. They're winning ugly."cite journalEvansSeanThe 25 Greatest Moments in White Sox Historyhttp://www.complex.com/sports/2012/04/the-25-greatest-moments-in-chicago-white-sox-history/winning-uglyApril 25, 2012[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]May 25, 2015The Sox went on to win the 1983 American League West division.

article.heading: Mascots
article.paragraph: File:Southpaw.jpgthumbrightSouthpawSee alsoList of Major League Baseball mascotsFrom 1961 until 1991, lifelong Chicago resident Andrew Rozdilsky performed as the unofficial yet popularmascot"Andy the Clown" for the White Sox at the original Comiskey Park. Known for his elongated "Come on you White Sox" battle cry, Andy got his start after a group of friends invited him to a Sox game in 1960, where he decided to wear his clown costume and entertain fans in his section. That response was so positive that when he won free1961 Chicago White Sox season1961season tickets, he decided to wear his costume to all games.cite newsSingerStaceyAndrew Rozdilsky, 77, Clown for Soxhttp://articles.chicagotribune.com/1995-09-24/news/9509240307_1_clown-international-harvester-home-openerSeptember 24, 1995Chicago TribuneMay 25, 2015Comiskey Park ushers eventually offered free admission to Rozdilsky.cite webLeyTomA Brief History of Terrible Chicago Mascotshttp://deadspin.com/a-brief-history-of-terrible-chicago-mascots-1501106550January 14, 2014[[Deadspin]]May 25, 2015Starting in1981 Chicago White Sox season1981, the new ownership group led by Jerry Reinsdorf introduced a twosome, calledRibbie and Roobarb, as the official team mascots, and banned Rozdilsky from performing in the lower seating level. Ribbie and Roobarb were very unpopular, as they were seen as an attempt to get rid of the beloved Andy the Clown.cite webWhite Sox History: The sad story of Ribbie and Roobarbhttp://www.southsidesox.com/2013/3/16/4106198/white-sox-history-the-sad-story-of-ribbie-and-roobarbMarch 16, 2013South Side SoxSBNationMay 25, 2015

In 1988, the Sox got rid of Ribbie and Roobarb, and Andy The Clown was not permitted to perform in new Comiskey Park when it opened in1991 Chicago White Sox season1991. In the early 1990s the White Sox had a cartoon mascot named, 'Waldo The White Sox Wolf' that advertised the Silver and Black Pack, the team kid's club at the time. The team's current mascot,Southpaw (mascot)SouthPaw, was introduced in 2004 to attract young fans.cite webPadillaDougSox: 'No grief about our mascot'http://espn.go.com/blog/chicago/white-sox/post/_/id/17962/sox-no-grief-about-our-mascotJanuary 23, 2014ESPN ChicagoMay 25, 2015
article.heading: Fight & theme songs
article.paragraph: Nancy Faustbecame the White Sox organist in 1970, a position she would hold for 40 years.cite newsCrouseKarenBallpark Farewell, Played Adagiohttp://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/18/sports/baseball/18organist.htmlSeptember 17, 2010[[The New York Times]]April 8, 2015She was one of the first ballpark organists to play pop music, and became known for her songs playing on the names of opposing players (such asIron Butterfly's "In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida" forPete Incaviglia).cite webVickeryHalFlashing Back with Nancy Fausthttp://www.whitesoxinteractive.com/rwas/index.php?categoryFlyingSock.comWhite Sox InteractiveMay 25, 2015Her many years with the White Sox established her as one of the last greatorganiststadium organists. Since 2011, Lori Moreland has served as the White Sox organist.cite newsAustenJakeAn organist transplant for the White Soxhttp://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/lori-moreland-chicago-white-sox-organist/Content?oidJune 30, 2011[[Chicago Reader]][[Sun-Times Media]]May 25, 2015
Similar to theBoston Red Soxwith "Sweet Caroline" and theNew York Yankeeswith "Theme from New York, New York", several songs have become associated with the White Sox over the years. They include:

list.listitem: Let's Go, Go-Go White Sox"Let's Go Go Go White Sox"byCaptain Stubby and the Buccaneers- A tribute to the "Go-Go White Sox" of the late 1950s, this song serves as the unofficial fight song of the White Sox. In 2005, scoreboard operator Jeff Szynal found a record of the song and played it for a "Turn Back the Clock" game against theLos Angeles Dodgers, whom the Sox played in the1959 World Series.cite webTheiserKellyGo-Go song revival a hit with fanshttp://m.whitesox.mlb.com/news/article/1254100/October 18, 2005White Sox official websiteMLB Advanced MediaMay 25, 2015After catcherA.J. Pierzynskihit a walk-off home run, they kept the song around as the White Sox went on to win the2005 World Series.

"Na Na Hey Hey Kiss Him Goodbye" bySteam (band)Steam- Organist Nancy Faust played this song during the 1977 pennant race when aKansas City Royalspitcher was pulled, and it became an immediate hit with White Sox fans.Faust is credited with making the song a stadium anthem and saving it from obscurity. To this day the song remains closely associated with the White Sox, who play it when the team forces a pitching change, and occasionally on Sox home runs and victories.cite webBrownDavidGoodbye, Paul Leka: Writer of sports anthem‘Na Na Hey Hey' dieshttp://sports.yahoo.com/mlb/blog/big_league_stew/post/good-bye-paul-leka-writer-of-sports-anthem-na-na-hey-hey-dies?urnOctober 24, 2011[[Yahoo! Sports]]May 25, 2015
"Sweet Home Chicago" - TheBlues Brothersversion of thisRobert Johnsonblues standard is played after White Sox victories.

article.heading: Rivalries
Crosstown Classic
article.paragraph: File:West Side Grounds 1905.jpgthumbrightFielder Jones of the White Sox hits the ball against Cubs at West Side Grounds, 1905MainCubs–White Sox rivalryTheChicago Cubsare theCubsWhite Sox rivalrycrosstown rivalsof the White Sox, a rivalry that some made fun of prior to the White Sox's 2005 title because both of them had extremely long championship droughts. The nature of the rivalry is unique; with the exception of the1906 World Series, in which the White Sox upset the favored Cubs, the teams never met in an official game untilbaseball year1997, when interleague play was introduced. In the intervening time, the two teams sometimes met for exhibition games. The White Sox currently lead the regular season series 4839, winning the last 4 seasons in a row. The BP Crosstown Cup was introduced in 2010 and the White Sox have won the trophy each time. There have been seven series sweeps since interleague play began: four by the Cubs in 1998, 2004, 2007, and 2008, and three by the White Sox in 1999, 2008 and 2012, with 1999 and 2012 occurring in Wrigley Field.

An example of this volatile rivalry is the game played between the White Sox and theChicago CubsatU.S. Cellular Fieldon May 20,baseball year2006. White Sox catcherA. J. Pierzynskiwas running home on a sacrifice fly by center fielderBrian Anderson (outfielder)Brian Andersonand smashed into Cubs catcherMichael Barrett (baseball)Michael Barrett, who was blocking home plate. Pierzynski lost his helmet in the collision, and slapped the plate as he rose. Barrett stopped him and, after exchanging a few words, punched Pierzynski in the face, causing a melee to ensue. Brian Anderson and Cubs first basemanJohn Mabrygot involved in a separate confrontation, although it was later determined that Mabry was attempting to be a peacemaker. After 10 minutes of conferring following the fight, the umpires ejected Pierzynski, Barrett, Anderson, and Mabry. As Pierzynski entered his dugout, he pumped his arms, causing the soldout crowd atU.S. Cellular Fieldto erupt in cheers. When play resumed, White Sox second basemanTadahito Iguchiblasted a grand slam to put the White Sox up 50 on their way to a 70 win over their crosstown rivals. While there are other major league cities and metropolitan areas in which two teams co-exist, all of the others feature at least one team which began playing there inbaseball year1961or later, whereas the White Sox and Cubs have been competing for their city's fans since 1901.
article.heading: Divisional
article.paragraph: The White Sox enjoy healthy divisional rivalries. TheDetroit Tigersare one of Chicago's primary rivals, and the cities of Chicago and Detroit share rivalries in other sports as well, such as theBullsPistons rivalry,BlackhawksRed Wings rivalryand theBearsLions rivalry. The rivalry has had its fair share of fights as well.

TheMinnesota Twinsare high-profile rivals as well, with fans of both teams showing up to US Cellular Field in healthy numbers. The White Sox and Twins also played in a one-game playoff in2008 American League Central tie-breaker game2008, the White Sox would win the game 10 and the division.

Chicago has another rivalry with theCleveland Indians, who always enjoy a large away contingent at U.S. Cellular Field. The rivalry first started upon the creation of the AL Central in 1994. On July 15, 1994 an umpire confiscatedAlbert Belle's bat, presuming that it was corked. They put it in the umpire's room at Comiskey Park. However, Indians pitcherJason Grimsleyclimbed through the ceiling from the visitor's clubhouse and stole the bat. The theft was discovered and Belle was suspended; Grimsley later owned up to the theft. Belle further inflamed matters by spurning the Indians and signing a large free agent contract with the White Sox in 1997.
article.heading: Historical
article.paragraph: A historical regional rival was the St. Louis Browns. Through the 1953 season, the two teams were located pretty close to each other (including the 1901 season when the Browns were the Milwaukee Brewers), and could have been seen as the American League equivalent of theCardinalsCubs rivalry, being that Chicago and St. Louis have for years been connected by the same highway (U.S. Route 66and nowInterstate 55). The rivalry has been somewhat revived at times in the past, involving the Browns' current identity, theBaltimore Orioles, most notably in 1983.

The currentMilwaukee Brewersfranchise was also a primary White Sox rival, due to the proximity of the two cities, and with the teams competing in the same division for the 1970 and 1971 seasons, and then again from 1994 to 1997. The rivalry died down however, when the Brewers moved to theNational Leaguein 1998.

article.heading: Radio
article.paragraph: File:Bob Elson circa 1940s.JPGthumb150pxElson in the 1940s.The White Sox did not sell exclusive rights for radio broadcasts from radio's inception until 1944, instead having local stations share rights for games.cite webAll-Time Broadcastershttp://chicago.whitesox.mlb.com/cws/history/broadcasters.jspWhiteSox.comMLB Advanced MediaOctober 11, 2014The White Sox first granted exclusive rights in 1944, and would bounce between stations until 1952, when the White Sox started having all games broadcast onWCFL (AM)1000 AM WCFL.cite webRight on Q: A brief history of the White Sox on the radiohttp://www.southsidesox.com/2014/5/17/5725462/white-sox-radio-historyMay 17, 2014South Side SoxSB NationMay 25, 2015Throughout this period of instability, one thing remained constant: the White Sox play-by-play announcer,Bob Elson. Known as the "Commander," Elson was the voice of the Sox from 1929 until his departure from the club in 1970.cite web1979 Ford Frick Award Winner Bob Elsonhttp://baseballhall.org/discover/awards/ford-c-frick/bob-elsonNational Baseball Hall of Fame and MuseumOctober 11, 2014In 1979, he was the recipient of theFord Frick Award, and his profile is permanently on display in theNational Baseball Hall of Fame.

After the 1966 season, radio rights shifted from 1000 AM to 670 AM,WMAQ (AM)WMAQ. AnNBCowned & operated station, it was the home of the Sox until the 1996 season (with the exception of brief stints onWRDZ (AM)1300 AM WTAQandWBBM (AM)780 AM WBBM). After Elson's retirement in 1970,Harry Caraybegan his tenure as the voice of the White Sox, on radio as well as on television. Although best remembered as a broadcaster for the rival Cubs, Caray was very popular with White Sox fans, pining for a "cold one" during broadcasts.cite web1989 Ford Frick Award Winner Harry Carayhttp://baseballhall.org/discover/awards/ford-c-frick/harry-carayNational Baseball Hall of Fame and MuseumOctober 11, 2014Caray would often broadcast from the stands, sitting at a table set up amidst the bleachers. It became a badge of honor among Sox fans to "Buy Harry a beer..." By game's end you'd see a large stack of empty beer cups beside his microphone. This only endeared him to fans that much more. In fact, it was with the Sox that he started his tradition of leading the fans in the singing ofTake Me Out To The Ballgame.cite webBohnMattHarry Carayhttp://sabr.org/bioproj/person/d6a6a34eSABR.orgSociety for American Baseball ResearchOctober 11, 2014Caray, alongside color analystJimmy Piersall, was never afraid to criticize the Sox, which angered numerous Sox managers and players, notablyBill MeltonandChuck Tanner. He left to succeedJack Brickhouseas the voice of the Cubs in 1981, where he became a national icon.

The White Sox shifted through several announcers in the 80s, before hiringJohn Rooney (sportscaster)John Rooneyas play-by-play announcer in 1989. In 1992, he was paired with color announcerEd Farmer. In 14 seasons together, the duo became a highly celebrated announcing team, even being ranked byUSA Todayas the top broadcasting team in the American League.cite newsGardnerSteveRooney, Farmer give White Sox AL's top radio teamhttp://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/2005-07-26-announcers-al_x.htmJuly 26, 2005[[USA Today]]May 25, 2015Starting with Rooney and Farmer's fifth season together, Sox games returned to the 1000 AM frequency for the first time in 30 years (now theESPN RadioESPN owned & operatedstationWMVP (AM)WMVP). The last game on WMVP was Game 4 of the 2005 World Series, with the White Sox clinching their first World Series title in 88 years. That also was Rooney's last game with the Sox, as he left to join the radio broadcast team of theSt. Louis Cardinals.

In 2006, radio broadcasts returned to 670 AM, now theCBS RadioCBS-Ownedall-sports stationWSCR, branded as 670 the Score. Ed Farmer became the play-by-play man after Rooney left, joined in the booth byChris Singleton (baseball)Chris Singletonfrom 200607 and thenSteve Stone (baseball)Steve Stonein 2008. In 2009,Darrin Jacksonbecame the color announcer for White Sox radio, where he remains today.cite webBroadcastershttp://chicago.whitesox.mlb.com/team/broadcasters.jsp?c_idWhiteSox.comMLB Advanced MediaOctober 11, 2014Farmer and Jackson are joined by Chris Rogney, who hosts pregame and postgame shows on WSCR. TheChicago White Sox Radio Networkcurrently has 18 affiliates in 3 states, and the White Sox are on contract with 670 the Score through the 2015 season.cite webRadio Afiliateshttp://chicago.whitesox.mlb.com/cws/schedule/radio_affiliates.jspWhiteSox.comMLB Advanced MediaOctober 11, 2014As of recently, White Sox games are also broadcast in Spanish with play-by-play announcerHector Molinajoined in the booth by Billy Russo.cite webWhite Sox Announce new Spanish radio broadcastershttp://m.whitesox.mlb.com/news/article/27702400/white-sox-announce-new-spanish-radio-broadcastersMarch 28, 2012WhiteSox.comMLB Advanced MediaPress releaseMay 25, 2015Formerly broadcasting onESPN Deportes RadioviaWEBGWNUA, games will begin to be broadcast onWRTO (AM)1200 AM WRTOduring the 2015 season.cite web2015 Broadcast Schedulehttp://mlb.mlb.com/schedule/broadcast/index.jsp?c_idOfficial Site of the Chicago White SoxMLB Advanced MediaMarch 4, 2015
article.heading: Television
article.paragraph: White Sox games appeared sporadically on television throughout the first half of the 20th century, most commonly announced by Jack Brickhouse on Channel 9,WGN-TV. Starting in 1968,Jack Dreestook play-by-play duties as the Sox were broadcast on channel 32,WFLD.cite webAll-Time Broadcasters- Televisionhttp://chicago.whitesox.mlb.com/cws/history/broadcasters.jspWhiteSox.comMLB Advanced MediaOctober 11, 2014After 1972, Harry Caray (joined by Jimmy Piersall in 1977) began double duty as a TV and Radio announcer for the Sox, as broadcasts were moved to channel 44,WSNS-TV, from 1972-1980, followed by one year on WGN-TV.

Don Drysdalebecame the play-by-play announcer in 1982, as the White Sox began splitting their broadcasts between WFLD and the new Pay-TV channel,Sportsvision. Ahead of its time, Sportsvision had a chance to gain huge profits for the Sox. However, few people would subscribe to the channel after being used to free-to-air broadcasts for many years, resulting in the franchise losing around $300,000 a month.cite webWhite Sox History: The story of SportsVisionhttp://www.southsidesox.com/2012/11/30/3707810/white-sox-history-the-story-of-sportsvisionNovember 30, 2012South Side SoxSB NationOctober 11, 2014While this was going on, every Cubs game was on WGN, with Harry Caray becoming the national icon he never was with the White Sox. The relatively easy access to Cubs games versus Sox games in this era, combined with the popularity of Caray and the Cubs being owned by theTribune Company, is said by some to be the main cause of the Cubs advantage in popularity over the Sox.

File:Hawk Harrelson 2007 CROP.jpgthumb235pxHarrelson in the broadcast booth in 2007Three major changes to White Sox broadcasting happened each year from 1989 to 1991: in 1989, Sportsvision was replaced by thecable TVchannelFSN ChicagoSportsChannel Chicago. In 1990, over-the-air broadcasts shifted back to WGN. And in 1991,Ken Harrelsonbecame the play by play announcer of the White Sox.cite webEdelmanAlexanderKen Harrelsonhttp://sabr.org/bioproj/person/442dbc70SABR.orgSociety for American Baseball ResearchOctober 11, 2014One of the most polarizing figures in baseball, "Hawk" has been both adored and scorned for his emotive announcing style. His history of calling out umpires has earned him reprimands from the Commissioner's office, and he has been said to be the most biased announcer in baseball.cite newsSelig reprimands Harrelson for rant against umpirehttp://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-06-01/sports/chi-selig-reprimands-harrelson-for-rant-against-umpire-20120601_1_umpire-friday-s-white-sox-seligJune 1, 2012Chicago TribuneMay 25, 2015However, Harrelson has said that he is proud of being "the biggest homer in baseball," saying that he is a White Sox fan like his viewers.cite newsDiamondJaredHow Biased Is Your Announcer?http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10000872396390444180004578016652376246198September 26, 2012[[The Wall Street Journal]]May 25, 2015

Currently, White Sox local television broadcasts are split between three channels: the majority of games are broadcast on cable by the regional sports networkComcast SportsNet Chicago(which the club has a 20% stake in), and remaining games are produced byWGN Sportsand are broadcast locally on eitherWGN-TVorWPWR-TV. WGN and WPWR games are also occasionally picked up by local stations in Illinois, Iowa, and Indiana. In the past, WGN games were broadcast nationally on theWGN Americasuperstation, but those broadcasts ended after the 2014 season as WGN America began its transition to a standard cable station.cite webFederRobertRobert FederWGN America comes home to Chicagohttp://www.robertfeder.com/2014/12/15/wgn-america-comes-home-to-chicago/December 15, 2014Robert FederyesMay 25, 2015WGN Sports-produced White Sox games not carried by WGN-TV were carried byWCIU-TVuntil the 2015 season, when they moved toMyNetworkTVstation WPWR-TV.cite newsShermanEdWhite Sox add WPWR-Ch. 50 to station rotationhttp://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/baseball/whitesox/chi-white-sox-channel-50-20150219-story.htmlFebruary 19, 2015May 25, 2015Chicago Tribune

The announcers are the same no matter where the games are broadcast: Harrelson provides play-by-play, andSteve Stone (baseball)Steve Stonehas provided color analysis since 2009.cite webBergerRalphSteve Stonehttp://sabr.org/bioproj/person/a906928eSABR.orgSociety for American Baseball ResearchOctober 11, 2014Games that are broadcast on CSN Chicago feature pregame and postgame shows, hosted by Chuck Garfein with analysis fromBill Meltonand occasionallyFrank Thomas (designated hitter)Frank Thomas.
